content:

disclaimer: 'Newsquawk source' - Signifies information that has not been formally tested through traditional journalistic channels and therefore is to be treated as unsubstantiated. Any interpretation of this information is taken at the reader’s own risk and is a representation of the rumours within the market place and never generated by ourselves

subject: WTI futures settle 66 cents lower at USD 70.70/bbl; Brent crude futures settle 35 cents lower at USD 77.12
analysis_details: Crude prices slipped on Friday amid reported profit-taking, but closed higher for the week after the US announced the prospect of new sanctions on Iran, with WTI +c.3% and Brent +c.2% for the week. In afternoon trade, crude hit session lows after sources reported Exxon boosted its crude unit production at its Baton Rouge Louisiana refinery, shrugging-off reports that Saudi Arabia intercepted a Houthi missile heading into Jizan, as reported by Al Arabiya. Baker Hughes weekly rig count data saw total rigs rise by 13 to 1045, oil rigs were up 10, and gas rigs were up 3. Elsewhere, Iraq raised its OSP for Basra Light crude (June) by $0.90/bbl versus the previous month, AND China raised retail fuel prices for the fourth straight week. Elsewhere, in the ~US, Texas energy regulators were reported to have issued 1221 drilling permits in April, up 34% versus a year earlier.

subject: NY Fed GDP Nowcast Q2 2018: at 3.0% (Prev. 3.0%)
Weekly FX Wrap: data, Central Banks and acquisitions the main impactors
content:
DXY

The index is ending a busy/volatile week on the defensive having set a new 2018 peak on Wednesday at 93.420, but easing back towards 93.000 by the close that day as strong technical resistance at 93.522 was respected and US PPI data was soft in places. The Dollar was subsequently dealt a further fundamental blow via soft elements within April’s CPI report and is now back below 92.500 (and lower than where it was on Monday).

GBP/CHF/EUR/AUD

All vying for Friday’s top G10 performer vs the Usd award, and remarkably the respective pairs are pretty close to where they started the week after roller-coaster rides on the back of Greenback swings and/or independent factors. Cable kicked off around 1.3535 and squeezed up to just over 1.3600 shortly before midday on BoE ‘super’ Thursday, but then hit a low near 1.3450 as the MPC held rates by a 7-2 majority and signalled no urgency (beyond the hawkish dissenters) to continue policy normalisation until it can be determined whether the sharp Q1 growth slowdown is temporary and weather related or not. Governor Carney added to the less hawkish guidance with  the view that it is likely rates will rise this year, but if the economy weakens policy can be adjusted accordingly. Usd/Chf is back below parity vs 1.0050+ at one stage after softer than forecast Swiss CPI data, while Eur/Usd has rebounded sharply from a new ytd low circa 1.1820 to 1.1950+ largely on a technical rebound with 1.1935-6 pivotal on the charts (key Fib and 200 HMA). Aud/Usd has also benefited from a short squeeze and broadly better risk sentiment overall, with option and hedge fund buying ahead of 0.7400, while cross-related flows also aided the recovery.

JPY/NZD/CAD

Narrowly mixed vs the Usd on the day, and the Jpy among those little changed over the week as upside tests of 110.00 were rejected and a base around 109.00 holds. The Kiwi has stabilised off 0.6900 lows vs its US counterpart, but remains weak on balance having lost the 0.7000 handle and sliding to 1.0800+ levels vs the Aud mainly on RBNZ impulses as the Bank maintained rate but said the OCR could be raised or lowered as risks are balanced. Moreover, new Governor Orr welcomed Nzd weakness in wake of the revised policy outlook/guidance. In stark contrast, the Loonie has ridden on the crest of rallying crude prices and more positive NAFTA vibes ahead of a meeting later today, and following reports that a deal could be reached by next week, with no real or sustained reaction to mixed Canadian jobs data (headline disappointing, but breakdown more encouraging). NAFTA impulses have also boosted the MXN, while the TRY has been very choppy between fresh record lows vs the Usd and recovery highs against the backdrop of Government-CBRT meetings to discuss the Lira’s plight and economy overall that promised a lot, but produced little concrete.

DAILY US EQUITY OPENING NEWS - Earning from NVIDIA (NVDA)/ Symantec Corp (SYMC)
content:
11th May 2018

Earnings

Dropbox (DBX) Q1 Adj. EPS USD 0.08 vs Exp. USD 0.04, revenue USD 0.316bln vs Exp. USD 0.310bln. (Newswires)

Flowserve Corp (FLS) Q1 EPS USD 0.27 vs. Exp. USD 0.26, revenue USD 0.92bln vs. Exp. USD 0.88bln. (Newswires)

Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR) Q1 Loss/shr USD 0.60 vs. Exp. USD Loss of USD 0.54, revenue USD 0.038bln vs. Exp. USD 0.04bln. (Newswires)

News Corp (NWS) Q1 EPS USD 0.06 vs. Exp. USD 0.06, revenue USD 2.01bln vs. Exp. USD 1.99bln. The Net loss available to stockholders increased to USD 1.13bln (USD 1.94/shr) due to a USD 1.2bln expense related to write downs after the deal with Telstra. (Newswires)

NVIDIA Corp (NVDA) Adj. Q1 EPS USD 2.05 vs. Exp. USD 1.47, revenue USD 3.21bln vs. Exp. USD 2.91bln. Cryptocurrency related purchases were higher than expected, however cloud computing orders were lower than expected. It also expects to see fewer crypto miners, but more gamers in the future. (Newswires)

Symantec Corp (SYMC) Q1 EPS Adj. USD 0.46 vs. Exp. USD 0.39, revenue USD 1.23bln vs. Exp. USD 1.19bln. The co. also forecasts FY results below analyst expectations. The Audit Committee of the board opened an internal investigation after concerns were raised by employees and stated the annual report may be delayed following a probe in its financials. (Newswires)

Thomson Reuters (TRI) Q1 Adj. EPS USD 0.28 vs Exp. USD 0.37, revenue USD 1.38bln vs Exp. USD 1.43bln. (Newswires)

DJIA

Apple (AAPL) – Rumours suggest the next iPhone will offer the GBP 999 iPhone X’s best feature at a much cheaper price. Also, Foxconn, the largest supplier to the tech giant, reported its April sales, which were higher than expected. Separately, the tech giant left its overseas cash out of its latest quarterly report. (Hot Apple News / Newswires)

Apple (AAPL) / Microsoft (MSFT) – Microsoft says it would like to work with Apple to bring iMessage support to windows. (9to5Mac)

Boeing (BA) – Executive J. Michael Luttig is selling 9,000 common shares at USD 344.13/shr. (Newswires)

Cisco (CSCO) – The co. is withdrawing its adverts from YouTube (GOOGL) after the ads appeared on sensitive content. (Newswires)

JP Morgan (JPM) – The bank is expanding its equity research by 50% on Chinese firms. (Newswires)

S&P500

General Motors (GM) – Korea Development Bank appears more cautious on the Korean unit and sees first profits in 2022 whilst the automaker sees profits coming in before that. (Newswires)

Interpublic Group (IPG) -  Director Greeniaus is selling 33,573 common shares at USD 24.1524/shr. (Newswires)

Mosaic (MOS) – The co. appointed Clint Freeland CFO. (Newswires)

Mylan (MYL) – The US Department of Justice is investigating Mylan on trade compliance for certain products. (Newswires)

Noble Energy (NBL) – The oil co. is approaching a final agreement to move the Permian crude oil to Corpus Christi. (Newswires)

PPG (PPG) – The chemical group announced errors in their March quarter report amid violations of accounting policies. The co. fired a controller as a result. The firm failed to include some expenses in the first quarter of the year and stated the FY17 financial statements 'should no longer be relied upon'. (Newswires/Marketwatch)

Range Resources (RRC) - Stelliam Investment Management, a major shareholder in the firm, is looking to vote against the board nominees brought forward by the co. (Newswires)

Auto names (GM, F, FCAU) –  Approaching the NAFTA deadline negotiators are finalising rules on autos and given the time constraints, it could lead to " the possibility of less drastic changes to other controversial parts of NAFTA, according to people following the talks." Separately, US President Trump is to meet with 10 major automakers to discuss the future of landmark fuel efficiency standards and an ongoing confrontation with major states. (WSJ/Newswires)

Health Names – US Health and Human Services Secretary Azar speaking to CNBC says US President Trump’s drug plan is to include 50 initiatives, and that Trump is to speak on the matter at 14:00ET/19:00BST. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

Alphabet (GOOGL) – The tech giant is considering joining Walmart (WMT) in its Flipkart investment. (CNBC)

Amazon (AMZN) – Google (GOOGL) has reportedly stopped purchasing shopping advertisements from the co. according to people familiar with the matter. (Newswires)

Microsoft (MSFT)/Alphabet (GOOGL) – Veteran DC lobbyist Pablo Chavez is leaving Microsoft to re-join Alphabet. (Newswires)

Qualcomm (QCOM) - The chipmaker extended the offer period for NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) to May 25th. (Newswires)

Tesla (TSLA) – Panasonic expressed concerns over its partnership with the automaker and turned more hesitant on the additional Gigafactory in the country. (Newswires)

T-Mobile (TMUS) – Sprint (S) reassures that the merger with the telecom firm will go ahead smoothly, after concerns were raised over Sprint's tie-up with Nextel Communications back in 2005. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

C Trip (CTRP) – Dalian Wanda is to sell a 5.11% stake in an online travel company for USD 186mln. (China Money Network)

Graco (GGG) - Director Van Sant sells 15,000 common shares at USD 45.6462/shr. (Newswires)

Snapchat (SNAP) – The redesign of the app was not appreciated by millennials and saw a 73% drop in US consumers aged 18-34. (Newswires)

World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE) - The co. has reached a deal to broadcast 'Raw' in the Philippines. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 11th May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Major FX pairs trading within short ranges. EM currencies finding some respite
  • European bourses flat on thin news flow ahead of the weekend
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian jobs report, Uni of Michigan, Baker Hughes, Fed’s Bullard and ECB’s Draghi

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks traded mostly positive after sentiment rolled over from the US where soft CPI data spurred hopes the Fed may have to slow the pace of hikes, while all sectors in the S&P 500 finished in the green with gains led by tech, telecoms and pharmaceuticals, which in turn underpinned NDX outperformance. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were positive with earnings also a key driver of price action and the top performing stocks in Japan spurred by corporate updates including KDDI, Panasonic and Suzuki. Hang Seng (+1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were mixed as Hong Kong sustained its outperformance streak, while the mainland lagged after the PBoC refrained from open market operations and widened the amount of liquidity it drained for the week. Finally, 10yr JGBs were quiet amid similar flat trade witnessed in T-notes and heightened appetite for riskier assets, while the BoJ’s rinban announcement also failed to spur demand with the amounts kept unchanged and at paltry JPY 285bln total for the day.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 140bln vs. last week's net drain of CNY 110bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3524 (Prev. 6.3768)

CENTRAL BANKS

BoE’s Broadbent says waiting to assess the economy is right and that rate hikes will be gradual. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

UK Environment Secretary Michael Gove is said to be concerned the EU could use the Northern Ireland border issue to hold the UK at ransom to keep it in the customs union. (Telegraph)

5 Star Movement and League government may be formed next week, and the parties will pass a flat tax and citizens income in 2019. (Corriere Della Sera) Next Italian PM could be an independent figure who is not part of either 5 Star or League, according to top 5 Star member. (Newswires)

US President Trump says hopes to strike a better deal with Iran. (Newswires)

Iran Foreign Minister Zarif is to meet with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang on Sunday, Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov on Monday and EU officials on Tuesday to discuss preserving nuclear agreement. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are mostly lower (Eurostoxx 50 -0.2%) with the exception of Spain’s IBEX (+0.2%). Looking at the sectors, health care is a noticeable underperformer amid negative drug updates from AstraZeneca (-0.3%) and Roche (-1.7%), subsequently dragging other health names across Europe (Novartis -0.7%, GSK -0.8%, Merck -0.9%) in sympathy. On the flip side, material names outperform following strong earnings from the world’s largest steelmaker ArcelorMittal (+1.7%) as it lifts the likes of Thyssenkrupp (+1.2%) with it. Elsewhere, Sika (+10%) rose to the top of the Stoxx 600 after striking a deal with France’s Saint Gobain (+2.4%) who are also seen higher on the news.

FX

USD

The Greenback is virtually flat vs G10 rivals and the index rangebound between 92.630-840 after its retracement from new ytd highs just shy of 93.500 to around 92.500 in wake of some softer than expected components in the latest CPI release and ahead of more price indicators via import/export data and inflation expectations in the Michigan survey.

AUD

A marginal outperformer, with Aud/Usd back up near 0.7550 and Aud/Nzd seemingly forming a more solid base above 1.0800. No lasting adverse effects on the back of weak housing data overnight as the broader risk tone remains relatively positive, while OTM option bids and hedge fund buying interest has been reported on dips.

NZD/CAD

Both marginally firmer vs their US counterpart, but the Kiwi continues to lag on dovish RBNZ policy guidance and a green light to sell the currency from new Governor Orr. Conversely, the Loonie is still benefiting from high crude prices and latest NAFTA negotiation updates suggesting a deal may struck by next week (May 17 to be precise), but eyeing upcoming Canadian jobs data for more fundamental direction. Nzd/Usd currently around 0.6970 and Usd/Cad circa 1.2750.

GBP/EUR/JPY/CHF

All virtually unchanged vs the Dollar, with Cable sustaining recovery gains above 1.3500 in consolidative trade after initial post-BoE super Thursday losses and getting another M&A boost from US-based Silver Lake’s purchase of Zoopla (Gbp2.2 bn deal). Eur/Usd looks hemmed in between 1.1900-50 amidst heavy expiry option interest at either strike and 1.1925 (3.8 bn in total) and awaiting a speech from ECB President Draghi. Usd/Jpy has retreated a bit further from recent 110.00 or so multi-top peaks, but appears supported just ahead of 109.00, while Usd/Chf has also slipped back towards the base of a 1.0000-50 band after briefly touching parity on Thursday.

TRY/MXN/SEK/NOK

The Lira is still holding the bulk of its recovery gains around 4.2500 vs the Usd on the premise that Turkish authorities will take action to stem its depreciation, while the aforementioned positive NAFTA developments are propping the Peso around 19.2500. Elsewhere, the Scandis have extended gains vs the Eur again on more hawkish regional Central Bank outlooks vs the ECB.

FIXED INCOME

Not much new from BoE’s Broadbent or Governor Carney after the post-meeting press conference yesterday, but UK debt and the STIR strip are paring more gains made on the knee-jerk response to confirmation of no change in rates and the prospect of only one more and done in 2018 as the majority of the MPC want to see how/if the economy bounces back after the partly weather related downturn in Q1. Gilts tried to tick up from a flattish open and reached 122.40 vs Thursday’s 122.34 Liffe close, but faded quickly alongside Bunds (after briefly extending their gains above 159.00 to 159.16) to 122.15 at worst so far. Similarly, Short Sterling contracts have handed back up to 3 ticks. Ahead, Bunds and EZ paper in general will be looking for impetus from ECB President Draghi while US Treasuries are holding a firmer line before more price data and survey expectations with yields settling off recent highs after yesterday’s CPI report and the last leg of refunding (long bonds relatively well received).

COMMODITIES

Oil is seeing profit taking heading into weekend as both WTI and Brent come off of recent highs, currently both down 0.3% and 0.1% respectively with newsflow relatively muted ahead of today's Baker Hughes rig count. In the metals scope, gold is currently trading flat on the day, with aluminium witnessing a slide for the second session in a row. Copper also slipping on the day, after peaks on Thursday due to shortened inventories, but still set to close positively for the week. Steel in the green for the day on growing Chinese demand.

subject: Future of Airbus (AIR FP) deal in Iran depends on future European policies and government support, senior Iranian official adds currently in talks with plane-makers to take advantage of the limited time frame
Italy sells EUR 6.75bln vs. EUR 5.25-6.75bln 0.05% 2021, 1.45% 2025 and 2.45% 2033 BTP
content:

  • EUR 2.5bln 1.45% 2025 b/c 1.34 (Prev. 1.40) and gross yield 1.34% (Prev. 1.27%)
  • EUR 1.5bln 2.45% 2033 b/c 1.68 (Prev. 1.62) and gross yield 2.38% (Prev. 2.45%)

subject: ECB says banks borrowed EUR 227mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 662.3bln; excess liquidity at 1.901tln
Bunds: pivoting around 159.00 ahead of ECB President Draghi
content: A relatively lacklustre start to Friday’s Eurex session as the 10 year German debt future seems caught between a firmer lead from US Treasuries that are consolidating post-CPI gains and deriving some comfort from no major digestion issues during this week’s quarterly refunding vs a rebound in Italian BTPs amidst reports that a coalition Government could be in place by this time next week. Bunds have ventured either side of the 159.00 level, albeit within a narrow band and almost exclusively below Thursday’s 159.07 close to a 158.92 low before finding some underlying bids. Ahead, no major data after another soft Eurozone inflation release from Spain, but multi-tranche Italian auctions could be interesting along with a speech from ECB President Draghi in the pm.

subject: Morning EU Movers: Sika (SIK SM) +10.0%, ArcelorMittal (MT FP) +3.3%, Thyssenkrupp (TKA GY) +1.1%, Air France (AF FP) -0.8%, GlaxoSmithKline (GSK LN) -0.5%, Novartis (NOVN SW) -0.5%, AstraZeneca (AZN LN) -0.7%, Roche (ROG SW) -1.2%

BoE’s Broadbent says waiting to assess the economy is right and that rate hikes will be gradual
RANsquawk Bond Auction Previews - 11th May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Italy to sell EUR 5.25-6.75bln 0.05% 2021, 1.45% 2025 and 2.45% 2033 BTP

 

AUCTION PREVIEW: Italian EUR 5.25-6.75bln 0.05% 2021, 1.45% 2025 and 2.45% 2033 BTP Auctions

IFR:

Given the lack of a viable marketfriendly political outcome, it’s not clear BTPs are cheap enough yet to attract much interest

BTPs have sold off from the prior midmonth auctions of April 12, largely as political uncertainty has reared its head again over the last week

BTPs have suffered on a crossmarkets basis too amid the political volatility

Competing supply is a little bit of an issue amid supply from Portugal, Germany, Netherlands, Ireland and Austria this week

In terms of historical data:

0.05% 2021 prev. b/c 1.28 and average yield 0.05%

1.45% 2025 prev. b/c 1.4 and average yield 1.27%

2.45% 2033 prev. b/c 1.62 and average yield 2.45%

Bids are submitted by 1000BST and results are published shortly after

Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
JP Morgan's stated preferred food and HPC shares: L'Oréal (OR FP), Essity (ESSITYB SS), Reckitt (RB/ LN), and Nestlé (NESN SW)

Bayer (BAYN GY) - The co. has received approval for Eylea in China, a treatment for visual impairment due to neovascular macular degeneration. (Newswires)

Zoopla (ZPG LN) - The co. is to be bought by Silver Lake for 490/pence per share in a cash deal valued at GBP 2.2bln. (Newswires) 

Ferrovial (FER SM) – Co. has proposed a EUR 275mln share buyback programme. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) - The co. has provided an update on GALATHEA phase 3 trial, it did not meet the primary endpoint of a reduction of exacerbations in patients with COPD. (Newswires)

Unione di Banche Italiane (UBI IM) - Q1 net profit EUR 117.7mln vs. Exp. EUR 84mln, CET1 ratio 11.64% vs. prev. 11.43%, net commission income EUR 407.3mln vs. prev. EUR 395mln  (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
11th May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded mostly positive after sentiment rolled over from the US where soft CPI data spurred hopes the Fed may have to slow the pace of hikes, while all sectors in the S&P 500 finished in the green with gains led by tech, telecoms and pharmaceuticals, which in turn underpinned NDX outperformance. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were positive with earnings also a key driver of price action and the top performing stocks in Japan spurred by corporate updates including KDDI, Panasonic and Suzuki. Hang Seng (+1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were mixed as Hong Kong sustained its outperformance streak, while the mainland lagged after the PBoC refrained from open market operations and widened the amount of liquidity it drained for the week. Finally, 10yr JGBs were quiet amid similar flat trade witnessed in T-notes and heightened appetite for riskier assets, while the BoJ’s rinban announcement also failed to spur demand with the amounts kept unchanged and at paltry JPY 285bln total for the day.

FTSE

Defence Names – The MoD’s refusal to secure an appropriate plan that is leading to a GBP 21bln “black hole” is reportedly making it impossible for defence companies to plan ahead. Separately, UK’s Labour leader said all Navy ships should be built in the UK as there has been speculation that a GBP 1bln contract for 3 new Royal Fleet Auxiliary support ships could go to a foreign shipyard. (BBC/Telegraph)

RBS (RBS LN) - UK government could sell a small part of its RBS stake before the summer, according to a source. (FT)

Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – The GBP 15bln merger with Asda is facing scrutiny by the CMA, new research shows at least 73 supermarkets will have to be sold in order for the proposed merger to be given the go-ahead. (BBC)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

SIG (SHI LN) – The co. has rejected Deliotte’s reappointment as its auditor months after it was found out that SIG was exaggerating profits. (Times)

Bovis Homes (BVS LN) – The co. is under investigation after some customers had been awarded rewards in return for positive surveys. (Independent)

BROKER MOVES

GREGGS (GRG LN) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT BERENBERG

DAX

Fresenius (FRE GY) – The co. has said that it would not take a financial hit if it were to go through with the acquisition of Akorn at the originally agreed price, as may be required by a US court. (Newswires)

E.ON (EOAN GY) / RWE (RWE GY) / Innogy (IGY GY) – The management teams of the three co.’s are set to meet to discuss the impact of a possible deal on jobs, with labour unions saying a basic framework could be agreed upon. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

UNIPER (UN01 GY) DOWNGRADED TO REDUCE FROM HOLD AT HSBC

CAC

St. Gobain (SGO FP) – Co. confirms Sika (SIK SW) deal. Co. will become a shareholder of Sika through SWH. Co. acquired all outstanding shares of SWH from Burkard family for CHF 3.22bln. Co. materializes a substantial positive net result in excess of EUR 600mln for shareholders through deal. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Air France (AF FP) – April load factor fell 0.4pp to 88.1%, RPK -2.6%, ASK -3.1%. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

ENI (ENI IM) – The CEO of the co. said they have recovered overdue payments from Iran, and notes they have no projects or investments in the country. (Newswires)

Ferrovial (FER SM) – Q1 revenue EUR 2.70bln vs. Prev. 2.89bln. EBITDA loss of EUR 75mln vs. Prev. EBITDA of 227mln. Q1 net los EUR 161mln vs. Prev. profit EUR 72mln. (Newswires)

ACS (ACS SM) – Q1 net profit EUR 250mln vs. prev. EUR 233mln, EBITDA EUR 627mln vs. prev. EUR 605mln, sales EUR 8.67bln vs. prev. EUR 8.36bln. (Newswires)

Unipol (UNI IM) – Q1 net profit EUR 163mln vs. prev. 157mln, solvency ratio 181%, direct business combined ratio 94.1%, direct insurance premiums net of popolare vita EUR 3.2bln. (Newswires)

Mediobanca (MB IM) – Q3 net profit EUR 205.6mln vs. Exp. EUR 180mln, revenues EUR 630.2mln vs. Exp. EUR 610mln, CET1 ratio 13.9% vs. prev. 12.9%, loan loss provisions EUR 60.3mln vs. prev. EUR 58.6mln. (Newswires)

ArcelorMittal (MT NA) – Q1 EBITDA 17.3% higher at USD 2.51bln vs. Exp. USD 2.33bln. Net income of USD 1.2bln vs. Prev. USD 1bln. Q1 sales USD 19.19bln vs. Exp. USD 18.48bln Steel shipment +1.7% at 21.3 metric tons vs. Exp. 21.6 metric ton, iron or shipment +3.6% YY to 13.8 metric tons. Outlook for 2018 has strengthened as year has progressed. (Newswires)

Banca Monte Dei Paschi (BMPS IM) – Q1 revenue EUR 877mln vs. Prev. EUR 802mln. CET 1 ratio 14.4% end-March vs. 14.8% end-2017, net EUR 188mln vs. Prev. loss of EUR 169mln. Co. started the process to sell EUR 2.6-3.0bln in bad loans this year. (Newswires)

Merlin Properties (MRL SM) – Q1 revenue EUR 124mln vs. Exp. EUR 120mln, EBITDA EUR 97.5mln vs. Exp. EUR 90mln. (Newswires)

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – The co. has provided results on Tecentiqs which showed using this treatment alone did not provide meaningful clinical benefit compared to Regorafenib, and a study evaluating a combination of Tecentriq and Cotellic did not meet primary endpoint of overall survival compared to regorafenib. (Newswires)

US

EQUITIES: SPX +0.94% at 2793, NDX +1.02% at 6964, DJI +0.80% at 24739.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: +0.35%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.73%, Energy: +0.81%, Financials: +0.71%, Health Care: +1.20%, Industrials: +0.74%, Materials: +0.79%, Technology: +1.13%, Telecoms: +1.80%, Utilities: +1.28%.

US equity futures rose from the Wall Street open and boosted from the slightly softer US CPI report which hints the Fed may decide to hike rates at a slower pace, also from a technical perspective the Emini broke back above 2700 and the April high.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks traded mostly positive after sentiment rolled over from the US. USD languished around the 92.50 level after a pullback from the YTD highs.
content:
Asian stocks traded mostly positive after sentiment rolled over from the US

In FX markets, USD languished around the 92.50 level after a pullback from the YTD highs.

Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian jobs report, Uni of Michigan, Baker Hughes, Fed’s Bullard and ECB’s Draghi

ASIA

Asian stocks traded mostly positive after sentiment rolled over from the US where soft CPI data spurred hopes the Fed may have to slow the pace of hikes, while all sectors in the S&P 500 finished in the green with gains led by tech, telecoms and pharmaceuticals, which in turn underpinned NDX outperformance. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were positive with earnings also a key driver of price action and the top performing stocks in Japan spurred by corporate updates including KDDI, Panasonic and Suzuki. Hang Seng (+1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were mixed as Hong Kong sustained its outperformance streak, while the mainland lagged after the PBoC refrained from open market operations and widened the amount of liquidity it drained for the week. Finally, 10yr JGBs were quiet amid similar flat trade witnessed in T-notes and heightened appetite for riskier assets, while the BoJ’s rinban announcement also failed to spur demand with the amounts kept unchanged and at paltry JPY 285bln total for the day.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 140bln vs. last week's net drain of CNY 110bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3524 (Prev. 6.3768)


UK/EU

UK Environment Secretary Michael Gove is said to be concerned the EU could use the Northern Ireland border issue to hold the UK at ransom to keep it in the customs union. (Telegraph)

PM May has delayed key Brexit legislation due to fears of defeat while her allies played down the prospect of any imminent deal over future customs policy. Allies to may believe that next Tuesday’s meeting is unlikely to provide a solution to the Irish border issue. (FT) Furthermore, after a meeting of the Brexit cabinet sub-committee last week broke down without agreement, May has appointed two new working groups on each of the rival solutions. (Times)
 

FX

In FX markets, USD languished around the 92.50 level after a pullback from the YTD highs seen mid-week and in the wake of the softer than expected CPI data. This kept its major counterparts firm, while GBP/USD was also off the post-BoE lows seen after the central bank kept policy unchanged and lowered Q2 2018 GDP forecasts as well as CPI forecasts through to Q2 2020. Elsewhere, commodity-linked currencies held on to the recent energy-triggered upside, while the greenback’s NAFTA-counterparts have also stayed near the prior day’s best levels after the broad USD-weakness and some optimism regarding a near-term deal.

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded sideways overnight as the complex took a breather from the recent upside in prices. As such, WTI crude future are marginally weaker but remain above the USD 71/bbl level with gains of over 2% for the week after the US withdrawal from the JCOPA. Elsewhere, gold prices were slightly softer overnight but remained near its best levels in nearly 2-weeks after recent USD weakness due to soft inflation data, while copper traded flat and failed to benefit from the overall positive risk appetite in the region. Conversely, Chinese metal prices were more eventful with early gains in iron ore and steel prices on expectations of increased demand amid declining rebar stockpiles.
 

GEOPOLITICS

Iran Foreign Minister Zarif is to meet with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang on Sunday, Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov on Monday and EU officials on Tuesday to discuss preserving nuclear agreement. In related news, US President Trump commented that he hopes to strike a better deal with Iran, while the US Treasury issued fresh sanctions on Iran in which it blacklisted several individuals and entities. (Newswires)

US

Treasuries finished slightly higher for the day, following the miss on CPI which alleviated fear of inflation gearing up in the economy. Yields on the long-end of the curve were lower by c.3bps at settlement. The 5s30s spread was the lowest since 2007 and narrower by c.4bps following the solid 27bln 30yr bond auction, which stopped-through by 0.8bps. The stop-through was the largest for a new bond at auction since November 2015. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 4 ticks higher at 119-15+.

US President Trump is to give speech on reducing drug prices at 1400EDT today, while President Trump had also commented that he has great health plans to be announced over the upcoming 4 weeks. (Newswires)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said he thinks China 'agreed to the concept' of reducing the trade deficit, while he also commented that there is a reasonable chance the US will reach a tariff deal with the EU. (Newswires)

US is said to set May 17th or May 18th for a NAFTA deadline, while House Speaker Ryan commented that Congress must receive the final NAFTA text by May 17th to be able to vote on it this year prior to the expiry of the fast-track Trade Promotion Authority in July and US mid-term elections in November. In related news, Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland said they will work as long as necessary for NAFTA and that she remains optimistic about reaching a deal, while she added they are definitely approaching the final objective. (Newswires/iPOLITICS)

subject: ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia stocks heads into the weekend mostly positive, although China lags following another liquidity drain while USD remains subdued post-CPI
content: Asia stocks traded mostly positive after sentiment rolled over from US where soft CPI data spurred hopes the Fed may have to slow the pace of hikes, while all sectors in the S&P 500 finished in the green with gains led by tech, telecoms and pharmaceuticals, which in turn underpinned NDX outperformance. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were positive with earnings also a key driver of price action and the top performing stocks in Japan spurred by corporate updates including KDDI, Panasonic and Suzuki. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were mixed as Hong Kong sustained its outperformance streak, while the mainland lagged after the PBoC refrained from open market operations and widened the amount of liquidity it drained for the week. Finally, 10yr JGBs were quiet amid similar flat trade witnessed in T-notes and heightened appetite for riskier assets, while the BoJ’s rinban announcement also failed to spur demand with the amounts kept unchanged and at paltry JPY 285bln total for the day.

subject: China is to increase gasoline and diesel prices

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks approach the weekend mostly positive; USD remains subdued post-CPI
content:
Asia stocks are mostly positive as sentiment rolls over from US where soft CPI data spurred hopes the Fed may have to slow the pace of hikes, while all sectors in the S&P 500 finished in the green with gains led by tech, telecoms and pharmaceuticals which in turn underpinned NDX outperformance. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) are positive with earnings also a key driver of price action and the top performing stocks in Japan spurred by corporate updates including KDDI, Panasonic and Suzuki. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) are mixed with Hong Kong sustaining its outperformance streak, while the mainland lags after the PBoC refrained from open market operations and widened the amount of liquidity it drained for the week.

In FX markets, USD remains subdued around the 92.50 level after a pullback from the YTD highs seen mid-week and in the wake of the softer than expected CPI data. This has kept its major counterparts firm, while GBP/USD is also off the post-BoE lows seen after the central bank kept policy unchanged and lowered Q2 2018 GDP forecasts as well as CPI forecasts through to Q2 2020. Elsewhere, commodity-linked currencies have held on to the recent energy-triggered upside, while the greenback’s NAFTA-counterparts have also stayed near the prior day’s best levels after the broad USD-weakness and some optimism regarding a near-term deal.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are quiet amid similar flat trade witnessed in T-notes and heightened appetite for riskier assets, while the BoJ’s rinban announcement was also ignored with the amounts kept unchanged and at paltry JPY 285bln total for the day.

subject: Sri Lanka Central Bank keeps key rates unchanged as expected with the Deposit Rate held at 7.25% and the Standing Lending Rate held at 8.75%
